So yes, we’ll admit it: We add miso to nearly...everything. But for good reason! Miso, a fermented mixture of beans and grains that has been a fundamental ingredient in Japan for millennia, is salty, earthy, funky, and/or sweet—depending on the type you choose. But before we get to all that, let’s slow down and review some miso 101.First, how is miso made?The standard base comes from soybeans, but other cooked legumes work too. Those legumes are fermented with koji, which are grains—like rice, barley, or millet—inoculated with the mold Aspergillus oryzae. From there, all it takes is time.There are so many different kinds. How do I know what to buy?There are countless varieties of this Japanese fermented soybean paste, but generally deeper color = bolder flavor. Look for unpasteurized organic miso from small local producers and avoid stabilizers, alcohol, or other additives like MSG. The only ingredients should be soybeans, koji, grains, salt, and water.This miso pesto recipe is a real BA favorite.
Photo by Alex LauBut wait, I’m still overwhelmed.The shorthand way to comprehend the wide world of miso is to divide it into two major camps. Light miso (like shiro miso, for example) is pale in color, with a relatively short fermentation time; it’s sweet and mellow and great for dressings, glazes, and baking projects. Dark miso (like aka miso) has a longer fermentation time and higher salt content, making it punchier, richer, and more intense; use in hearty stews and braises.South River Miso has a bunch of different kinds, all fermented for varying lengths of time.
Photo by Chelsie CraigDo you have a favorite kind?We love South River Miso Co.’s small-batch miso, hand-crafted in Masachussetts the Japanese tradition. Read more about it here! Buy it: $11–$17 for 16 oz. on southrivermiso.com.Where do I store it?Miso will keep indefinitely in the fridge: Store in an airtight container, like the one it came in, with a piece of parchment paper or plastic wrap pressed against the surface.What do I do with it?You can use a dollop to amp up marinades, pestos, salad dressings, stir fries, mayo, or vegetable stock.Yep, there’s miso in there.
PHOTO BY CHELSEA KYLE, FOOD STYLING BY FRANCES BOSWELLDo you have a salad dressing with miso you love?Purée 6 Tbsp. fresh lemon juice, 6 Tbsp. tahini, 1⁄4 cup extra-virgin olive oil, 2 Tbsp. white or yellow miso, 2 tsp. maple syrup, 11⁄2 tsp. onion powder, 1⁄2 tsp. garlic powder, and 1⁄2 cup water in a blender until smooth. Season with salt and pepper.Any other ideas?Salty, earthy, bitter, and toasty—miso is a perfect complement to brown butter, nuts, and caramel.
